narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The proposed study on adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience mechanisms will generate a diverse range of scientific data. This includes demographic and clinical datasets, standardized anxiety and resilience scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures such as heart rate variability, derived summary variables, and associated documentation (e.g., protocols, data dictionary, README files). The estimated amount of scientific data is substantial due to the longitudinal multi-modal datasets collected across multiple time points. Physiological data and raw task files are expected to represent the largest portion of storage.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated from this project will be preserved and shared, with the exception of any information that could potentially compromise the privacy or confidentiality of human research participants. The rationale for preserving and sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and further research in the field of adolescent mental health, particularly regarding anxiety symptoms and resilience processes. Sharing these data aligns with the principles of maximizing the benefit of research investments and promoting scientific progress.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata and associated documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, informed consent documents, data collection instruments (including survey tools and behavioral task descriptions), data dictionaries, and README files explaining the structure and content of the shared datasets. These materials will be deposited in a publicly accessible repository, such as ClinicalTrials.gov for study protocol and informed consent information, and other relevant platforms like Zenodo or similar for survey tools and code.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate some of the shared scientific data. For instance, statistical analysis software (e.g., R, Python libraries) may be required for manipulating and analyzing the datasets, especially for derived summary variables and physiological measures. Additionally, specific software might be necessary for viewing or working with certain types of behavioral task data. These tools and software will be specified in the documentation accompanying the shared data to facilitate their use by other researchers.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. For demographic and clinical datasets, standards such as those recommended by the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) for clinical research will be followed. For physiological measures, data will be formatted according to standards established in the field of psychophysiology. When applicable, data will also adhere to the FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) to maximize their utility for the broader scientific community.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: Scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in a reputable, publicly accessible repository. Given the focus on mental health research, repositories such as the NIMH Data Archive or similar platforms that specialize in hosting clinical and behavioral research data will be considered.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers (e.g., DOIs) for datasets and associated publications. Standard indexing tools and metadata tags relevant to adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience mechanisms will also be utilized to enhance discoverability.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available as soon as possible but no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The duration of preservation and sharing of the data will be permanent, ensuring that these resources remain accessible to the research community over the long term.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Given that this project involves human subjects, particularly adolescents, factors such as informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality protections will affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of the scientific data. Specifically, all shared data will be de-identified to protect participant privacy, and access may be controlled for certain sensitive datasets. Justifications for any limitations on data sharing will be based on ethical considerations and legal requirements, including those related to the protection of human subjects.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to certain components of the scientific data, particularly those that could potentially compromise participant confidentiality even after de-identification, may be controlled. This control mechanism will involve a review process for requests to access these sensitive datasets, ensuring that use is limited to legitimate research purposes and that users agree to terms of use that protect participant privacy.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all data shared will be de-identified. This process will involve removing or altering direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and potentially sensitive indirect identifiers that could lead to participant identification. Additionally, the project will adhere to the terms of the informed consent provided by participants and their parents/guardians, which includes broad consent for de-identified data sharing. Certificates of Confidentiality may also be used as an added protection for sensitive information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the research institution's data management and compliance offices. Regular oversight meetings will be conducted at least bi-annually to review progress, address any issues related to data sharing or privacy protection, and ensure that all project staff are trained on and adhere to the policies outlined in this plan. The PI will also be responsible for reporting any changes or updates to the Plan to the funding agency as necessary, ensuring ongoing compliance with NIH's Data Management and Sharing Policy.
